## Canary Media
news articles are in this form: 
https://www.canarymedia.com/sitemaps-1-section-articles-1-sitemap-p16.xml

newsletters (which require subscription) are in this form:
https://www.canarymedia.com/sitemaps-1-section-newsletters-1-sitemap-p1.xml
### Repeated similar workflows for others news-aggregators

## Fetch and process the sitemap.xml file
This part fetches and process the sitemap.xml file from XML data to JSON that we can work with.

## Carbon Capture Magazine

This news-aggregator site does not have any RSS feed, neither is it possible to navigate through pages of articles (go to https://carboncapturemagazine.com/ and click "articles" or "news", I was not taken to the anticipated page for articles and news respectively).

As an alternative, I discovered that this site has a sitemap.xml, which is basically a text-based XML file that lists all the important URLs (web pages) on a website, acting as a roadmap for search engine crawlers.

A quick scan allowed me to filter the sitemap to article links only, ignoring general pages like "about", "advertising", "newsletter" etc.

After several trial executions, this sitemap has the following features:

1. It's arranged from the oldest to recent articles (hence the 'Analyse last 100 article URLs' node)

2. URLs contain the title of articles, not the publication dates.

Challenges:
The HTML extract node does not recognise the CSS selector that represents the main content. I found a JSON-like portion in the article's HTML that contains the attributes of the article. I only took the attributes:

* title
* publishedAt (pubDate)
* tags > name (categories/keywords)
* summary (content snippet)
* body (contains main content, but with other stylistic features irrelevant to the content)

Set up a scheduled read of the last 30 links of the sitemap that runs every 3 days at midnight. 

Carbon Capture Magazine's articles are published quite sparsely rather than on consecutive days.

nodes.name: Check If Article Exists3
